inclusiveTime.title: Inclusive Time
inclusiveTime.description_wTags:
It is important to understand that the Bible uses an inclusive reconing of time which can be foreign to our modern, Western, exclusive reconing about time.

To illustrate, only a full year after birth would we moderns say that a baby is one year old, i.e., they have been alive for a year. In Ancient Isreal, as soon as they were born, it would have been said that they were one, i.e., they were in their first year.

Applying this to a Biblical example, in Gen5:32 when we read, "Noah was 500 years old, and he fathered Shem, Ham, and Japheth," we moderns should understand it to mean that he was what we would call 499 years old and "in his 500th year" when he became a father. This has obvious implications on dates, and is something to keep in mind.

project.title: Project
project.description: This project began in 2020 as a quickly hobbled together collection of PHP and CSS I threw together over a weekend just to visualize and verify some things I was reading about. Fast forward to 2024, where I have revisited the idea, but this time set out to build it properly — from the ground up, with modern web dev tools — into something that will hopefully be more usable for, not just me, but anyone who might find it useful!
project.description2_wTags: While I have included many options to accommodate differing views, interpretations, and sources, I doubt I have covered all scenarios. In other words, I am in no way claiming any sort of expertise on this topic ... but I'm also not claiming to come to this completely without opinion either. Mostly, though, I just wanted to do something with my development skills that might help someone else. Feel free to send me a message if you think there's something that could be improved or added, or if you are so inclined and able, the code for this project is available on Github for you to fork and tinker around with yourself.

ages.title: Manuscript Source
ages.description_wTags:
The ages of Adam through Terah found in Genesis 5 & 11 differ between the Masoretic Text (MT), Hebrew scriptures dating to the 2nd century AD, and the Septuagint (LXX), the Greek translation of the scriptures dating back possibly to the 3rd century BC (and I'm not going to bother with the Samaritan Pentateuch which appears to have a lot of problems in this area).

There are a whole host of factors indicating that the LXX should be trusted over the MT with regards to these dates (with a couple of exceptions). In particular, I have heavily referenced <0>the work of Henry B. Smith Jr. of the Associates of Biblical Research on the topic, and the "$t(options.ages.best)" option is based on his assertions: mostly following the LXX.

It's important to note that, despite the preponderance of evidence, and by what I would consider a quirk of history, all English bible translations — even the most recent (and I can't speak for translations in other languages) — are still using the ages found in the MT.

I recommend keeping this option set to "$t(options.ages.best)", but I have included the ability to set the timeline to use solely the MT or the LXX for the patriarch ages.

margins.title: Margin of Error
margins.description_wTags:
When constructing a Biblical timeline there is going to be some margin of error on all of your dates. This is inescapable by virtue of how the Bible lists birth years in Genesis; the Bible will list the year a person had their first child, but was that child born at the beginning of that year, the end, or somewhere in the middle? Naturally, that places a ±6mo margin of error on all dates of birth for the patriarchs (save Adam) which compounds to about a ±10yr margin of error for all subsequent dates.

A common method around this is to just assume that placing all of these birth dates at the middle of the year will more-or-less average itself out. Technically it's less precise, but likely gets you pretty close — in essence, the margins of error are still there, you just won't see them.

jubilee.title: Jubilee Years
jubilee.description_wTags:
Leviticus 25 mandates the observation of a sabbath year (the "shmita") every 7th year and a jubilee year every 7 shmita. Apparently, there is some wiggle room for interpretation on just when the jubilee year occurs in relation to the shmita cycle. Below are the three different methods for calculating the jubilee year that I have seen floating around out there:

• Inclusive: Each jubilee year overlaps with each 49th (shmita) year.

• Exclusive: Each jubilee year begins after each 49th (shmita) year and overlaps with the 1st year of each new shmita cycle (49-year cycles)

• Intercalated: Each jubilee year begins after the 49th (shmita) year and interrupts the shmita cycle with an intercalated (inserted) year. The first year of the next shmita cycle begins after the jubilee year (50-year cycles)

crucifixion.title: Crucifixion Date
crucifixion.description_wTags:
There is some dispute as to the exact year that Jesus was crucified. Here you can set what A.D. year the timeline uses for the Crucifixion.

For a more detailed discussion on the topic, see the relevant section in the notes.

NOTE: All Gregorian dates on the timeline are calculated from this date.
